awd_titl_txt: Target Infusion Project:  Transforming Physics Courses Using the Scale-Up Active Learning Model
awd_abstract_narration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) through Targeted Infusion Projects supports the development, implementation, and study of evidence-based innovative models and approaches for improving the preparation and success of HBCU undergraduate students so that they may pursue science, technology, engineering or mathematics (STEM) graduate programs and/or careers. The project at North Carolina Agricultural & Technical State University (NCA&T) seeks to transform course delivery in the physics gatekeeper courses by adapting and implementing the Student-Centered Active Learning Environment with Upside down Pedagogies (SCALE-UP) model. The activities and strategies are evidence-based and a strong plan for formative and summative evaluation is part of the project.

This project has the specific goals to: build and implement the SCALE-UP model for the four Introductory Physics gateway courses; build a community of practice for student centered learning; and build a strategic pipeline for high-achieving STEM students by attracting and retaining talented students in STEM majors. Each year, the four targeted courses will enroll approximately 1,300 students from the STEM disciplines.  Based on results from a pilot project with this approach, it is expected that this approach will increase students' conceptual understanding, reduce failure rates, improve performance in subsequent courses, develop faculty teaching expertise, and increase the retention rate of physics majors.

por.por_cntn:
The Department of Physics at North Carolina A&T State University (NC A&T) developed this project to transform course delivery of introductory physics courses and associated labs by adapting and implementing the Student-Centered Active Learning Environment with Upside-down Pedagogies (SCALE-UP) model. The SCALE-UP format is a student-centered method that promotes active learning and integrates lecture and laboratory work into one. The project piloted several versions of the SCALE-UP model, including a full SCALE-UP, as well as a hybrid form, which includes all the interactivity and engagement of the SCALE-UP method with the exception that the labs are not integrated into the lecture. Student performance and attitude toward learning were measured through gains on the Force Concept Inventory (FCI) standardized test for Physics I, the Brief Electricity and Magnetism Assessment standardized test (BEMA) for Physics II, analysis of the Colorado Learning Attitudes About Science (CLASS) survey data, student class attendance, and course student grades. A comprehensive analysis of these performance measures indicates that the SCALE-UP model positively impacts student success. We observe increased student conceptual understanding, better ability to solve physics problems, overall higher class attendance, and reduced failure rates. Based on these positive results, the Department of Physics plans to expand the implementation of the SCALE-UP model to most introductory physics sections as well as to some other advanced physics courses.


Recruiting, retaining, and graduating minority students in STEM is a national challenge. Improving student learning and performance in these gateway physics courses contributes to student success in STEM disciplines. The fact that 84% percent of NCA&T’s total undergraduate enrollment is African American gives this project more significance as it helps improve diversity in the STEM disciplines and contributes to addressing the nation’s chronic short supply of underrepresented STEM graduates.


This project engaged and trained not only faculty from physics but also faculty from chemistry and construction management in transformative course delivery and student-centered instruction. It led to fostering a culture of responsibility and commitment to inquiry, ownership, and engaged learning. Faculty continuously improved their SCALE-UP teaching skills by being receptive to student needs, adjusting their curriculum, and adapting the implementation of the scale-up pedagogy. Persistence has led to the desired results. To sustain this effort beyond the duration of the project, we are working on establishing a Center for Research and Innovation in STEM Education and Student Success. It will serve as hub for faculty involved in this project and others to promote and advance research, innovation, and best practices in STEM teaching and learning and student success.
